segments.text: They were people who were physically disqualified, but for some reason that I've forgotten were still eligible to go to school.
But just five people who were not a member of the Corps.
Then everybody, essentially everyone, got equal treatment, whether it was mistreatment or not.
But when you have a core of 2,000 or 3,000 out of 35,000 or even out of 4,000 for that matter, that's an entirely different situation.
And while I would like to see the benefits of what I consider benefits of hazing be a part of the school, under the conditions that we have now, I don't see how in the world it possibly could be.
So it's for lack of an answer to that question that I have to agree that we shouldn't have.
Okay.
Now, what do you see as the benefits of hazing?
Under the circumstances that it was possible to do so, I see I think several benefits of it.
I have to say here that when I say hazing, it's not just hazing as such.
It is the discipline that is enforced in part by hazing.
Hazing becomes a part of that discipline.
Hazing per se I don't see any benefit in.
But as it relates to that discipline, it teaches people how to think, teach them how to be patient.
It teaches how to remember names, as one little example.
It teaches you, the young kid at that time, that damn it, you have some backbone if you can just find a way to use it.
It teaches you you can have some patience.
You don't have to blow off the handle.
As a matter of fact, it teaches you you better find a way to do it.
And a number of things that it teaches you, I think, that are very, very good.
And they are particularly so if you're going to be into an occupation

where these kinds of things are important, such as in the military, flying airplanes, in the missile business, in the space business, things that require really almost in some cases superhuman discipline of mind and thought, and certainly control of your physical actions.
And I just think it contributes, properly done, contributes a great deal in that respect at that time in your life.
Needless to say, I don't think I need anybody to beat me over the head at this age about that.
Sounds like hazing was one of the things that you liked about the Corps.
What were other things that you liked about being in the Corps?
Well, yes, I did like it.
I mean, I liked what I stood for, yes.
I don't think it's a highlight.
Well, I think I just have to say I liked almost everything about the Corps.
It provided a means of association with others and a very
constructive way.
It provided the structure for social activities, which involved other people, bringing people from outside, girls, parents, spectators, all kinds of people.
It provided an outlet to a great deal of knowledge and kinds of knowledge that most of us at that time had had no opportunity to observe, even.
Unless you lived in San Antonio, one would probably never see a military unit, even marching, much less in action.
And so I enjoyed the horses.
I was in the field artillery and of course it was horse drawn at that time.
Sure.
And I loved horses.
I had grown up with them.
I had broken horses.
So that was very interesting.
As a result of the horses being available, we had horse shows, jumping contests, and all these kinds of things, which I participated in and won several of them.
Did you like the uniform?
The uniform, per se, to me was a necessity, not necessarily a necessary evil, but it was a necessity, and I had to admit that it was good for several other points of view.
I certainly couldn't have bought suits or clothes to wear during that period of time.
all of us, I think, would always remake whatever uniform we had because we didn't like the particular things about it.
But we most likely wouldn't do any better, so that you can just say is a normal crime.
Yes, overall I can say I liked the uniform.
I didn't go out and try to strut it or anything like that, but it was
distinct you.
At least somebody didn't ask you if you were from Georgia Tech or something.
You didn't come walking down the street.
Was there anything about being in the Corps that you disliked?
No, I don't think so.
When I was a brand new freshman I could think of several things, but overall I don't think there was nothing that
that I didn't like about it.
Did you ever gain a position of leadership in the Corps?
Well, I guess it depends on
what they call leadership.
I thought so.
What was it?
In my junior year, I was the first sergeant of this Battery D field artillery.
And in my senior year, I was the battalion commander of the second battalion of field artillery.
Those are pretty coveted jobs.
I don't know
I'm always interested in when young men start to assume, young men who become generals start to assume leadership roles.
When was that for you?
Oh, I guess it was while I was here.
In the Corps.
I think so.
I think so.
I'm thinking back on your career.
What ways do you think that being in the Corps helped you become a general?
I think it taught one how to recognize things that were important at an earlier time.
It also taught that
there was an answer to a problem if it came up and it gave you a direction to go and and solving that problem not an understanding of people but i think one's effectiveness in getting
to the bottom of most any problem as an understanding of the people who are working with that problem, and the people who have to be convinced about it in order to get a solution to it.
And one's association in the core certainly helped with that knowledge, helped develop that knowledge.
both with respect to those that you're working with as well as those you were working for.
So it helped you deal with people.
Yes.
Know people, understand people.
Most of the problems have to do with just that.
Do you think that there was any way in which being in the Corps hindered your career?
No, I can't think of any way that it could have hindered my career.
Not in any way.
Okay.
Do you think it had, you've already said that it seemed to have some impact on your becoming a leader.
Yes, I think it had a very substantial impact.
Okay.
Let's talk for a minute about the professional soldiers that were at A&M at the time.
Do you remember any of these professional soldiers and how did they help you?
I certainly do remember.
They helped me in many ways.
The commandant at the time was a man, Colonel Nelson.
known as Bull Nelson because he was the commandant and therefore the bull, but and needless to say I didn't get to know him very well.
The tactical officer for the field artillery was a major Sloan at that time, a very exacting and good field artillery officer.
The tactical officer of our, my unit was a Captain T.C.
Harry and he was an older officer, retired shortly after he left A&M.

but an absolutely wonderful man with a wonderful wife and he was here the whole four years that I was here and I think some while after I was gone but at least for those four years and while I was here I met a girl over in Huntsville who was later my wife and she came over to
visit me at various times and would stay at their house.
They lived off campus in what's now the town of Palisades, the city of Palisades.
And so I got to know them as wonderful people, real fine people.
The title clause for the Corps of Engineers here at the time was Captain Pick.
who was later General Pick and in charge of building the Burma Road, and later still of course became chief of engineers.
When Captain Pick was here as a captain, and I was first sergeant of a battery, we had a substantial disagreement about who was present for Reveille.
and he raised an uncommon amount of hell about it.
With the result that I had to go to Major Sloan, who was a field artillery officer and explain it, which I did.
And got the thing cleared up, but with some pretty hard feelings.
When I was in India,
as Deputy Chief of Operations for the Air Force.
Colonel Pick was working on the Verma Road and I went down to see him as a Brigadier General to talk with him.
We got things straightened out, everything was fine, but it was kind of an ironic meeting.
Major Sloan went on to Italy during the war and had command of a division there.
I didn't find out what happened to him after the war, so I don't know where he was, but he was a major general there in command of the division and the last I heard of him.
A real fine man.
What influence did they have on you?
Well, different in all of the cases, I guess.
Major Sloan left a lasting impression of military efficiency in my mind.
And Captain Harry, one of adequate military efficiency, but one of deep human understanding.
both qualities were very good, I thought.
They were very plus.
And I noticed the same qualities in varying degrees with the other types of classes.
There were several others here, not just those three that I mentioned.
How about the quality of training, as far as the artillery was concerned?
I thought it was very good.
very good.
In retrospect, I don't quite see how it was so good because it was quite realistic with all things considered.
We had the guns, the caissons, the horses, the harness, the everything else, and we hooked them up and drilled them and deployed and did all the things that you would do in war, including firing.
We didn't fire here, we fired over at Camp Bullock, but we did everything.
And I thought the quality of the training was very good.
It was the tools that you work with, and a number of other things changed a long time before World War II came on.
Sure, absolutely.
It was still fairly good.
What did you think of the quality of Second Lieutenant that came out of A&M back then?
Well, since I was one of them, I thought it was very high.
But watching it since that time,
I still think it's very high, very high by comparison to others.
Okay, let's compare it with some of the others.
Let's compare it with some of the other ROTC schools like VMI or some of the others like Virginia Tech or Georgia Tech.
Well, I've had some jobs since then that put me in contact with those various schools in their ROTC matters and all.
and without any desire to be derogatory in the slightest way, because they have some wonderful people and a wonderful program.
Most of them just do not have the capacity to expose their students, young second lieutenants coming up, to the kind of experiences and realism that we have here to do.
They just can't do it.

all these things cost money, and it's a very precious commodity in most of these places, because the military schools all over the country just do not get the kind of support that they need to have, and don't get the kind of support that A&M provides for itself in one way or another.
So I still think they're the best.
When I say comparative, the one out of West Point doesn't have any edge on these as far as I know.
Okay, so let's talk for a minute about the ones out of West Point.
How would you compare their training?
I haven't been through West Point training.
No, but of course you've met tons of West Point second lieutenants.
And you've had them work for you.
Yes, I have.
they are very good and they are very well trained.
But I don't feel that they're any better trained than they are out of A&M.
And in terms of their relationship with people, I'm not sure they're as astute or as sensitive to it as our people out of here are.
What do you mean by that?

If you're attuned to deal with people, when someone discusses something with you, you can be sympathetic enough to understand his thinking and to have the proper respect for whether you agree with it or not.
Having done so, then, you're in a very much better position to influence this thinking to what it is that you want it to be to get your job done, whatever that is.
I just don't think a lot of the people in West Point can reach out and grasp this in a real understanding way, and therefore not quite as effective.
an A&M second lieutenant or an officer come on a base and live with the people for a week, he usually got them all in his hands.
The West Pointer, of course, some of them do.
They're exceptions to all of them.
But most of them are busy with other things and they aren't looking too closely at that.
And we don't really have that rapport with the rest of the
people they're associated with.
Often I've heard from military men that there's a West Point club, a Ringknockers club, and all of this stuff.
What do you think about that?
Well, I know that there is some of that.
I've never been really faced with it in any way that was bad, and so I really don't have much thought about it.
overall I think it's not a good idea, but I can't cite that as an example of why it isn't.
But as far as career advancement is concerned, do you think that West Point people are favored over A&M as far as advancing in the military?
Well, I have to say it depends on how many of their class are in controlling positions when their number comes up for promotion.
Certainly there is some
some influence there.
Overall, generally, I think it's not really too significant.
But there is some.
I think the important thing there is that in our military we keep a relative balance so that you essentially eliminate that problem.
What do you mean a relative balance?
Well, if Air Force, for example, if they were composed entirely of West Pointers or now Air Academy people, there just wouldn't be room for guys from A&M or other places.
And they wouldn't get promoted, not because people were trying to deal unfair with them.
It just doesn't work that way.
As a practical matter, it doesn't work that way.

So, I think it important to Air Force that they have infused into their organization at all levels enough people to keep this sort of thing from happening, whether it be dominated by the Air Academy or dominated by A&M or whoever.
If we can keep enough in there to keep a balance, then it'll never be a problem.
Let's talk about your academic career at A&M.
What did you think of the quality of your professors?
Did you get very close to any of them?
I did get very close to them.
in the classroom sense.
I didn't get close to it socially or anything like that.

But I must say that as far as I'm concerned I had, for the most part, in my professors, the most wonderful people I've ever known, the most dedicated people I've ever known, and very knowledgeable people, and they would do nearly anything
to see that you learned what it was they were trying to teach.
And in chemical engineering, I had the same professors a lot more, I think, than you would have now in most courses.
And some of them as much as three years
I'd have a course under them all the time for three years, which I did have in the case of Dr. Bauer and Dr. Jensen and some others.
And I just thought that I can't say enough good things about them in terms of
how they went about their job, their dedication to their job, and their ability as teachers.
Then they were good.
You didn't have this problem around here, though, that you have now.
I mean, if you didn't want to learn, no one was going to waste thirty minutes fiddling with you.
If you wanted to work and learn, then you were willing really to work.
Now, they'd stay up all night or anything else you want.
But they didn't have time to fiddle with anybody who was even lukewarm about it.
You'd just get a zero and go explain to somebody else why.
Usually that was a one-way ticket home.
What did you think of your student colleagues?
Do you think they were pretty good students?
Were they really trying hard?
The people who were here?
Yes, if you remember in 28 to 32, it was about the roughest, well I guess that the nation is known, I don't know.
And the people that were here were mostly just by the skin of their teeth financially.
And if they didn't want to be here,
And one mention of this to most of their fathers, I'm sure would have got them home in a hell of a hurry.

So as far as I'm concerned, the people who were here as students at that time with just almost negligible exception were really top notch people in terms of wanting to do, wanting to learn, and working real hard at doing that.
guess it's probably overall the hardest working bunch of people that have probably ever been here.
It was pretty tough going as far as just making ends meet.
The school did everything in the world to help us all, individually or otherwise, just to stay here.
Do you think that they did a good job as far as educating you?
Did you feel prepared to go out and be an engineer when you were finished?
Yes, I may have been under some kind of illusion, but I felt like an engineer.
And I didn't get a chance to prove it, because in 32, when I graduated, there was absolutely no one that had a job to go to to find out.
As far as I know, not one of my class had a job.
Not even one.
They want most of them home to work in their father's business or something else, just because there were no jobs.
When I was a junior, I had the promise of three jobs open to me as soon as I graduated.
They were anxious to have me.
But hell, even the guys that were hiring me were not even there when I graduated.
No kidding.
They'd been closed down.
things were in pretty bad shape.
I went back to San Angelo and took a job with the Texas Public Service Company.
It was a gas company at the time.
Digging a ditch for two dollars a day as a chemical engineer.
And I expect I was doing just about as well as most of the rest of my classmates.
The jobs just were not there.
Often during conversations you hear people say that there's something special or something unique about Texas A&M.
Do you think there is something special?
Yes, I think the whole school is special.
If it were just a special thing it probably wouldn't last.
It's a whole combination of things that make it special.
One, I think, of the biggest of those in the beginning and on through to now has been the military and the discipline that is involved in it.
I know a lot of people are not interested in hearing that, but it's still a fact.
the further we go away from it, the less individual it's going to be, or the less special it's going to be.
Maybe there's something else that can generate a special condition, but right off hand I can't think what it's going to be.
But it provided a means for people to get to, people meaning students,
to be forced to know each other, and to be forced to learn some things that their families couldn't teach them, and to get on their own feet early.
And then I think that makes for a special situation.
Because despite the fact that a lot of the schools in Texas used to like to compare us
farm boys and people from the dairy barns, even to the extent of saying that we smell that way, the NMP people still stood out in groups that included students from other colleges.
That's not to say that they weren't fine guys in other colleges, but overall the N.M. guy still stood out.
He didn't always smell like a red bar.
I was wondering about your military colonel.
Let's start in on that.
In 1932 you graduated and then you
first started your air training in 1933.
During that one year interval then you were digging ditches.
That's right.
How did you get into the Army Air Corps?
Half of them.
I graduated to troubleshooters helper before I got to the end of that year.
How did I do that?
How did you get into the Army Air Corps?
While we were still here at A&M my senior year, a commander of D Battery, a man named Amy of Louisiana was just living until he could get out of here and get into flying.
they gave a physical exam before he graduated from here, and he failed it.
He was turned down for entrance to flying school.
And trying to console him when he got that news, which was pretty hefty news when that's the only job that you've got any prospect of getting.
I said, well, maybe you aren't so broken up, beat up physically, that you can't find yourself a reasonable job somewhere else.
He took it a little bit differently than I intended it, and said, hell, I'll bet you fifty bucks you can't pass the physical either.
Well, I didn't have that in mind, but so I told him I could, and I'd take it then.
So I applied, and it took almost a year, about eight months before I heard from him.
And it was a long application to fill out.
Well, as I began to get closer to this, then I began to really be interested in, sure enough,
not only passing the physical, but everything else it took to go on and get into it and get started.
And so following up that application then, I was notified, I don't know when November I believe it was, that I could report to Randolph for a physical exam.
at a certain time.
I went down to Randolph, and there were 600 people reporting in there in three days for the same physics exam for the same class.
No kidding.
And what was the size of the class?
The class was going to be about 200.
And that 600 had already been weeded out of like 12,000 applications.
many of whom had taken the exams locally, physical exams, locally in Minneapolis or wherever, and these were the ones that had survived that.
So, they were 600 out of a real big group.
So, reported down there for that physical at the proper time, and
At the end of the first day, there were about 20 of us left that hadn't been told we were going home.
At the end of the second day, there were eight of us left.
And at the end of the third day, or noon on the third day, when they finally got through, there were still these same eight of us left.
So, eight of us got in out of that 600.
And we didn't know it then.
They just told us that they'd pass us on a physical.
But we were notified in January, I guess it was, to report on February 20, 1933, which we did.
And that year,
graduates of West Point and Naval Academy, there was not enough money to commission them.
So the Naval Academy commissioned its upper half, upper half of its class.
The Air Force offered the other Naval Academy graduates, those that were not commissioned,
an opportunity to go through flying school if they could pass the physical and other things, and be commissioned in the Air Force Reserve.
Well fifty-something, fifty-two or three of them took advantage of this opportunity, and so they were, that group was there in my class in flying school.
So that's
some of the vacancies went to try to take care of that.
To indicate how bad things really were, we went on through our year of training and there was not money enough to commission us our second lieutenant.
When you finished?
When we finished.
We went to active duty as cadets for a year, that's right.
Well, it happened that on the day that we graduated, my class graduated, was the day that Franklin Roosevelt ordered the Air Force Corps to take over the mail.
So, I found myself a few days later, never having been west of El Paso or north of Amarillo,
flying a mail from Cheyenne, Wyoming to Salt Lake City, Utah in open cockpit airplanes for $75 a month, less 15%.
Why less?
One of the economy measures that was taken during that year was to cut all military pay by 15%.
Just didn't have the money in the budget to pay it.
So all of us were reduced 15%.
When you're on 75 bucks a month, they get it reduced 15%.
It hurts.
And so you graduated from the Air Corps Flying School in February 20th, 1934, and how long did you fly the mail?
Well, they took the mail over that day.
The Air Corps took it over that day.
And I went from Randolph, where we graduated, or from Kelly, where we graduated to Marchfield for a station in California, and then moved on up.
So, it was a month after that before I got even close to the mail.
And we finished flying the mail on July 25th, and so it was like two and a half months.
Now, I've heard some pretty negative responses about flying the mail, the Army Air Corps.
And as I understand, there was a high casualty rate.
There was a very high casualty rate.
You betcha.
Why was that?
Why was there a high casualty rate?
Yeah.
What were the problems?
You're all certified pilots.
There were three or four reasons.
There were.
One of them is that it turned out that during that period of time they had the worst weather for flying that I guess they've ever had before or since that anyone knows about.
It was really bad.
But that's not the primary reason.
The primary reason was that
We had been so strapped for money, the armed services had been, the Air Corps in particular, that we didn't have the equipment to do it.
The equipment that we're using, of course, was not made for it.
No.
We were not equipped in terms of navigation aids, which is the main reason for it.
either in terms of having the equipment, having it installed in the airplane, or having the training for it.
Well, I took off from Salt Lake City in a big Curtis B-2 bomber that I'd never been in before.
It was the biggest airplane that the United States owned at that time.
On the floor of the cockpit over in front of my crew chief was a box about like this.
And I asked the cruiser what it was, and he said, that's so you can receive the beam.
Well, that's the first time I ever heard of a beam, so I don't know what the hell that meant either.
Well, it turns out, when I got an education on it before I got back onto an airplane, after I finally got down that night,
they had installed these stations that transmitted in eight elliptical transmission patterns.
This one and this one were A, this one and this one were N. And if you were in the shadow between them, you got a solid signal.
If you set the station up and you set the shadow so it would write down your airway,
you could come in following that steady signal and come into the station and you'd know you were there.
There wasn't a lot more to it than that, but that's the theory.
So you'd know that you were approaching that city.
That's right, and you'd know which one it was.
The technique of doing this, though, on bad weather, bad static, and swinging beams, and all kinds of other things, is another matter.
how you know you're there, because you can fly through that cone in less than a second.
And this one going out the other way sounds exactly the same, unless you check to see whether you've got an A or an N on your right and so forth.
I mean, you have to orient yourself.
But if you didn't even know what it was, you certainly didn't know how to use it.
That's for sure.
And most of us were in that kind of category.
We hadn't even seen one yet.
So the training was another reason for our high-tech solar grid.
Oh, yes.
We didn't have that to train on.
We were flying in airplanes whose service ceiling wasn't as high as the mountains on the routes that we were flying.
It was a real rough decision.
I don't mind to say that now, that the President ought to be
for making that kind of decision or anything like that.
It had some good things, too.
It did, as I understand, break the airline monopoly that they had, which could have caused, did cause a hell of a problem.
But it also showed the Air Force and showed the world that unless you did something, you just didn't have an Air Force.
You can't win a war in PT with threes.
What about the morale?
We began to get some, it was terrible in many ways.
The pilot morale?
Well, it was good despite the fact, I've forgotten how many we lost, but it was like 80 or so pilots.
You lost 80 just from California?
No, not just Cal.
I'm talking about all over.
Okay.
And I don't know that that's any, I don't, that's not an exact figure, but it's close to that.
But we understood why we lost them and we just tried every way in the world that we could try to assure that we weren't the next one and
So was the pilot morale good then or bad?
You said horrible at first, and I said I was a morale man.
No, you said I was a morale man.
I was thinking about overall, everybody, and I said terrible.
Okay, so overall it was different then?
Yeah.
The pilot morale, as such, I think was very good.
Very good.
Why was it different between the entire Army Air Corps and the pilots?
people just didn't see very much sense in it.

Yet the pilot saw that it was extremely important because it was going to have to tell us what we had to do, and it was going to have to tell the nation what it was going to have to do before we could be a fighting unit.
I think it was good.
I lost some mighty good friends and damn near became one of them myself.
You had a close call?
Oh yeah, well I've had several.
Where was that?
It was Salt Lake City.
I'd come in to land and just a cold that couldn't retain your consciousness and
